Topic.Title: Scam stox are pimplez on the ars of finance

Message.Msg: Sybs: I neither expect nor count on anything. But, I continually record questionable activities to build a record for posterity's sake. If I was really trying to pursue something there, I could reach far more directly to more pertinent people. I was just highlighting that something is amiss here to someone who has seen a lot... My intent was to warn you. Several on this board can verify the screen capture. It was surreal... Amazon's LT economics really are screwed. Sure, it is gaining margin on vendor financing and 3P, at the cost of internal gross profit. It is now taking credit risk (at exactly the wrong time). The physical goods business will decline in relative competitiveness with WMT and TGT. The digital side is just now getting real competition.

Message.Msg: No way. CMG was a vastly better run company with superior unit economics and a very clear niche. Amazon has ZERO strategic focus, does NOT have a superior cost structure (and WMT/TGT's advantage will be growing) and has opened a 3 front war against better resources competitors. For all the pumping on AMZN, this years revenue growth rate will DECELERATE from last year's. Normally, folks do not expand multiples on decelerating revenue growth (and wildly negative earnings growth).

Message.Title: First time in 15 years Retailers may see disappointing holiday sales
Message.Msg: NEW YORK (MarketWatch) — A leading tracker of shopper traffic on Wednesday cut its seasonal sales forecast, saying the holiday selling period would have “a different tone” in the aftermath of the school shootings in Connecticut, superstorm Sandy and as talks drag on over avoiding the fiscal cliff. “It’s a change in mind-set,” said Bill Martin, founder of ShopperTrak, which follows shopper traffic in malls. “Gifts may not be as important as spending time with family. This holiday season is just not going to be as robust.” ShopperTrak cut its holiday season forecast to a 2.5% increase in November and December, down from its original projection of a 3.3% gain in September. It was the first time in the firm’s 15 years of predicting holiday sales that it cut its view midseason, Martin said in an interview. ShopperTrak’s numbers show sales and foot traffic in the week ended Dec. 15 were down 4.3% and 4.4% respectively, while ShopperTrak had expected both measures would increase with less than two weeks to go before Christmas. Traffic and sales also were down in the week ended Dec. 8. Despite strong Thanksgiving week sales, including the crucial Black Friday, retailers’ November sales have already turned out disappointing as they weren’t able to make up for lost demand from superstorm Sandy. Retailers’ November miss raises holiday stake. Friday’s school shootings in Connecticut, superstorm Sandy and fiscal cliff discussions “have put a damper on the holiday season,” Martin told MarketWatch. “We would have expected sales and traffic to go up (by now), but we’ve not hit that.” http://www.marketwatch.com/story/retailers-may-see-disappointing-holiday-sales-2012-12-19?link=MW_home_latest_news

Message.Title: American Funds and Other Mutual Fund Holders
Message.Msg: I'm not sure how much American Funds paid for amazon stock, I would guess 50.00 per share or less. I noticed that Growth Fund of America and American Balanced Fund have large positions in Amazon I know there philosophy investing is to take a long term position. But with this type of investment gain you would think that some type of realized gain would take place just to hedge their positions. I think amazon makes most of their money from third party sellers similar to what e-bay does with auctions. My advise is to stay away from trading this stock both long or short. There are other stocks to make money in the stock market. Very unpredictible situation.

Topic.Title: American Funds and Other Mutual Fund Holders

Message.Msg: American Funds (Capital World) bulked up first in 1Q2010 from less than 2 million to 8.5 million and again in 2Q2010 doubled their holdings to over 17 million and bought in the $120 to $140 range and since then have waxed and waned to a current 24 million or so level. They bailed out Bill Miller / Legg Mason after his fund imploded on bad Lehman bets. Bill Miller was a big Amazon cheerleader in the last decade and had a big Amazon position in his fund. Lately, American seems to be adding just as T.Rowe has been trimming its position. Let's see how the musical chairs plays out and the stock kept aloft by the cartel and who in the end is left holding the bag. Perhaps some hapless pension fund, sovereign fund together with index and closet index funds?

Message.Title: Jeff Jordan on the death of bricks and mortar
Message.Msg: Saying Best Buy cannot compete with Amazon simply does not mean that retail cannot compete with Amazon. Most categories are not well suited toward Amazon's model. Amazon has already achieved significant market penetration in the electronics segment. The underlying economics depends upon whether the category is an "experience good" or a "hard good" and depend upon the value density of the item. There are a great many product categories where the holding more inventory in a highly distributed fashion in retail space (particularly in warehouse space like Costco or Sam's) is simply more cost efficient (cost effective) than delivering it to someone's door. And, that tradeoff is getting worse for Amazon over time... Best Buy is no longer Amazon's competitive set. Costco, WalMart and Target are (although they each have far higher margins and higher cash flows yet COST and TGT together have the an enterprise value significantly less than ScAmazon...). The comparison to dying niche retailers is not intellectually honest.

Topic.Title: American Funds and Other Mutual Fund Holders

Message.Msg: Well, they are taking a very big gamble. At some point, state pension funds will realize that Amazon is not only directly but indirectly undermining state tax revenues (due to lower velocity of money in the local economy as it is shipped off to HQ) and decide to pull out of direct and indirect investments in Amazon. Local buying will make a comeback as all local economies realize the impact that Amazon has. And yes, the big box national retailers are better for local economies (although not as good as local retailers) than Amazon. The heat will certainly get turned up in 2013 as state struggle with revenues and reduced federal support. It isn't just the direct tax issue.

Topic.Title: Wonder when the state pension funds will require GPs to exit Amazon?

Message.Msg: Sears' Eddie Lampert too was regarded as an infallible money manager and his letters to shareholders were widely quoted to highlight his "vision" similar to many now infatuated with Bezos who rationalize every valuation metric and performance deficit as merely validating his grand script from his 1997 "Day 1.. It's All About the Long Term" letter to shareholders. And Eddie Lampert too articulated a similar "long-term" vision in his own 2007 letter to Sears shareholder: ".. by focusing on the long term, making decisions based on facts and logic, and appreciating that all decisions are based on many possible future scenarios, companies can navigate the ups and downs of the economy and the stock market to create long term value for their shareholders. That is our focus, and our goal, at Sears Holdings." And if we search for letters by Bernie Sanders and Jeff Skilling to their shareholders I am sure they too articulated similar lofty "long-term" visions for their companies.
